questions.text: Scabies, an infection of the skin caused by Sarcoptes scabies, is an example of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Scabies is a water-washed disease, meaning its spread is related to poor personal hygiene and lack of water for washing. The transmission is primarily through direct skin contact, but cleanliness and regular bathing play a key role in preventing infestation, making it dependent on the availability of water for hygiene rather than the water itself being a source.

Explanation of other options:

Waterborne disease (Option A): Infections transmitted through ingestion of contaminated water (e.g., cholera, typhoid) - scabies is not transmitted via drinking water.

Water-based disease (Option C): Caused by pathogens that spend part of their life cycle in water (e.g., schistosomiasis) - not applicable to scabies.

Water-related disease (Option D): Includes vector-borne diseases like malaria that require water for the vector's habitat - scabies does not involve vectors or stagnant water.

Key Takeaways:

  • Scabies is linked to hygiene, not water as a vector or medium.
  • Water-washed diseases result from inadequate water for personal cleanliness.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of a 6-year-old with intensely itchy skin lesions as shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Scabies typically present with intensely pruritic papules and burrows, especially in the interdigital spaces, as seen in the image. It is caused by Sarcoptes scabiei, and the itching worsens at night. In children, lesions may also appear on the trunk and extremities. The history of close contact and family members with similar complaints further supports the diagnosis.

In immunocompetent adults, the face is spared in typical scabies due to sebaceous skin, thin stratum corneum, and behavioural factors, but involvement may be seen in infants and immunosuppressed due to reduced resistance.

Explanation of other options:

Atopic dermatitis (Option A): Usually presents with chronic, flexural involvement, dry skin, and history of allergies or asthma, not typically limited to interdigital spaces.

Juvenile psoriasis (Option C): Involves well-demarcated plaques with silvery scales, usually over extensor surfaces, not consistent with intense itching in web spaces.

Drug reaction (Option D): Often involves widespread erythema or morbilliform rash with systemic signs, typically not localised to hands or interdigital areas.

Key Takeaways:

  • Scabies affects web spaces with intense nocturnal itching.
  • Burrows and contact history are diagnostic clues.
  • Locations Involved Usually
  • Examination findings include serpiginous white lines indicating mite burrowing and are typically located in intertriginous areas. Erythematous papules can form as a type IV hypersensitivity reaction to the mite, eggs, or excrement.

choices.text: Between fingers, on the wrists, and around the waist

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient presents with severe itching for two months. This itch is relentless, especially at night. Examination findings are shown below. What is the common distribution of this infestation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Scabies infestation commonly affects warm, moist areas such as interdigital spaces, flexor aspects of the wrists, periumbilical area, axillae, buttocks, and genital regions. The classic distribution pattern reflects the mite's preference for thin skin. The intense nocturnal pruritus and presence of burrows are diagnostic clues.

Explanation of other options:

Neck, hands, and face (Option A): Involvement of face and scalp is more common in infants, not adolescents.

Wrists, ankles, and legs (Option C): Legs are not a primary site in typical scabies; wrists are correct, but ankles and legs are less commonly involved.

Scalp and flexural surfaces (Option D): Scalp is usually spared in older children and adults; flexural surfaces may be involved but not specific to scabies.

Key Takeaways:

  • Scabies typically affects thin skin areas like interdigital spaces and flexor wrists.
  • Nighttime itching is a hallmark feature.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female patient with no significant past medical history presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of itching of the scalp. Physical examination of the scalp is notable for white or yellow beady structures. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pediculosis capitis (head lice) is the most likely diagnosis given scalp itching and presence of white/yellow nits (eggs). The first-line treatment is Permethrin 1% lotion, which is a topical pediculicide with ovicidal activity. It is applied to the scalp and washed off after 10 minutes. Reapplication after 7-10 days is often recommended to kill any newly hatched lice.

Explanation of other options:

Ketoconazole shampoo (Option A): Used for seborrheic dermatitis or tinea capitis, not effective against lice.

Permethrin 5% lotion (Option C): Reserved for scabies, not for head lice; may cause more irritation on the scalp.

Oral ivermectin (Option D): Used in resistant or recurrent lice infestations, or when topical therapy fails or is not feasible.

Key Takeaways:

  • Permethrin 1% is the treatment of choice for head lice.
  • The presence of nits and itching suggests pediculosis capitis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old homeless man presents to the dermatology clinic with the complaints of intense itching on his body for the last few days. Observation of which of the following parts will most likely help in the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This clinical scenario is consistent with pediculosis corporis (body lice), which commonly affects homeless individuals or those with poor hygiene. The lice do not live on the body but in the seams of clothing, coming onto the skin only to feed. Therefore, inspection of clothing seams is most likely to yield the diagnostic clue-lice or nits-rather than direct skin examination alone.

Explanation of other options:

Groin (Option A): Not a preferred area for lice infestation in pediculosis corporis.

Skin folds (Option C): More relevant in fungal infections or intertrigo, not pediculosis corporis.

Skin lesions (Option D): May show excoriations or secondary changes, but lice are not typically found on the skin in body lice infestations.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pediculosis corporis requires examination of clothing, not just skin.
  • Body lice live and lay eggs in clothing seams, not on the body.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 34, Page Number: 21

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents with a one-week history of localised swelling and redness on his face. He also complains of a mild headache, fatigue, and body aches. He returned five days ago from a month-long mission trip to El Salvador, central America. Physical examination demonstrates a 2.5 cm elevated, erythematous, indurated lesion with a central hemorrhagic punctum on his left cheek. There is no fluctuance or evidence of surrounding cellulitis. Examination of the eye shown below. Which arthropod is the most likely vector of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of periorbital swelling (Romana sign) following travel to Central America (Such as El Salvador) is characteristic of acute Chagas disease, caused by Trypanosoma cruzi. The vector is the kissing bug (Triatomine bug), which defecates near the bite site; the parasite enters through the bite or the mucosa. The Romana sign occurs when the conjunctiva is inoculated, leading to unilateral painless periorbital oedema, as shown in the image.

Explanation of other options:

Mosquito (Option A): Vector for diseases like malaria, dengue, Zika, not associated with Chagas or this presentation.

Sand flea (Option B): Can cause tungiasis, which affects the feet, unrelated to periorbital oedema.

Bot fly (Option D): Causes cutaneous myiasis with larvae under the skin, typically not associated with Romana sign or systemic features.

Key Takeaways:

  • Romana's sign is a hallmark of acute Chagas disease.
  • The triatomine (kissing) bug is the vector for Trypanosoma cruzi.

choices.text: 5% permethrin cream applied twice each day for 3 weeks
5% permethrin cream applied from the patient's head to toes and washed off after 8 to 14 hours
1% permethrin cream applied once each day for a week
5% permethrin cream applied from the patient's head to toes and washed off after 5 hours

questions.text: A 1-year-old infant presents to the clinic with itchy, exudative skin lesions as shown below. There is a positive family history of scabies. Which medication should be prescribed, and how should it be administered?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation and image showing vesiculopapular lesions on the foot, especially in an infant with intense itching and a positive family history of scabies, are classic for infantile scabies. The lesions are typical of burrows and papules seen on the soles, palms, and face in infants, which are less commonly involved in adults. 5% permethrin cream is the first-line treatment and is safe for infants older than 2 months. It must be applied from head to toe, including the scalp and face, and left on for 8-14 hours before washing off. In addition, all household contacts should be treated simultaneously, even if asymptomatic, to eliminate the infestation and prevent reinfestation due to close contact.

For adults, 5% permethrin is also the treatment of choice, but it is applied from the neck down and similarly washed off after 8-14 hours. A repeat application after 7 days is recommended in both cases.

Explanation of other options:

5% permethrin cream applied twice each day for 3 weeks (Option A): Overtreatment, increases risk of irritation and is not recommended.

1% permethrin cream applied once each day for a week (Option C): Incorrect strength-used for head lice, not effective against scabies.

5% permethrin cream applied from the patient's head to toes and washed off after 5 hours (Option D): Insufficient contact time - 8 to 14 hours is required for full effectiveness.

Key Takeaways:

  • Vesiculopapular lesions on soles and scalp suggest infantile scabies.
  • Permethrin 5% is the treatment of choice in both infants and adults.
  • All close contacts must be treated simultaneously to prevent reinfestation.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male returns from Africa, where he was involved in building a school. He presents with an asymptomatic skin lesion on the dorsum of the Left foot. What is the most appropriate initial treatment option?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cutaneous larva migrans (CLM) is caused by non-human hookworms, particularly Ancylostoma braziliense. Not all hookworm species produce this condition, only those unable to complete their life cycle in humans penetrate and migrate within the epidermis, creating a serpiginous, slowly advancing rash. The lesion typically moves at a rate of millimetres per day, helping to distinguish it from larva currens. The dorsum of the foot is a classic site following barefoot exposure in endemic areas.

Explanation of other options:

Larva currens (Option B): Caused by Strongyloides stercoralis, moves rapidly (centimetres per hour), and typically affects the perianal or trunk area, not the foot.

Calabar swelling (Option C): Seen in Loa loa infection, causes transient localised swellings, not serpiginous tracks; associated with migrating adult worms.

Myiasis (Option D): Results from fly larvae infestation, producing nodular swellings with a central punctum - no creeping pattern.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cutaneous larva migrans moves slowly (mm/day); larva currens moves rapidly (cm/hr).
  • Only certain hookworms like Ancylostoma braziliense cause CLM in humans.

choices.text: Burrow is present in stratum granulosum
Burrow appears yellow on wood's lamp
Burrows are located in the distribution - hebra circle
Burrow is a classical sign of scabies

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about the Burrow of scabies except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Scabies burrows are pathognomonic tunnels formed by the female Sarcoptes scabiei mite as it penetrates and moves within the stratum corneum, not the stratum granulosum.
  • In immunocompetent individuals, infestation with as few as 10-15 mites can cause the disease.
  • The typical incubation period is about 2-6 weeks in primary infestation (shorter in reinfestation due to hypersensitivity).
  • Burrows are typically found in the Hebra's circle and appear as serpiginous grayish lines.
  • Under Wood's lamp, they may fluoresce bluish-white, not yellow. Importantly, in animal scabies, though there can be intense pruritus, burrows are absent in human skin due to the inability of animal mites to complete their lifecycle in humans.

Explanation of other options:

Burrow appears yellow on woods lamp (Option B): Incorrect - scabies burrows fluoresce bluish-white, not yellow.

Burrows are located in the distribution - hebra circle (Option C): Correct - includes wrists, web spaces, genitalia, and axillae.

Burrow is a classical sign of scabies (Option D): Correct - burrows are the hallmark lesion, confirming diagnosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Burrows are found in the stratum corneum, not granulosum.
  • Disease may manifest with only 10-15 mites in immunocompetent hosts.
  • Burrows are absent in zoonotic (animal) scabies in humans.

questions.text: A 32-year-old lady presents to the dermatology OPD with itching over the pubic area at night. The examination findings are shown below. What is the probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows lice and nits attached to pubic hair shafts, with surrounding erythematous papules, typical of Phthirus pubis (crab lice) infestation
  • Patients usually present with intense nocturnal pruritus due to hypersensitivity to louse saliva, which contains anticoagulant compounds.
  • This saliva causes irritation and small hemorrhagic spots (maculae ceruleae). Mode of spread is primarily through sexual contact, although close personal contact or infested fomites (e.g., towels, bedding) can also transmit the parasite.
  • Pubic lice can occasionally infest other coarse body hair such as the axilla, beard, or eyelashes.

Explanation of other options:

Pediculosis corporis (Option A): Lice resides in clothing seams, not pubic hair; causes truncal pruritus.

Pediculosis capitis (Option B): Involves scalp hair, not pubic region.

Scabies (Option D): Involves Sarcoptes scabiei causing burrows, especially in web spaces-not visible lice or nits.

Key Takeaways:

  • Phthirus pubis is sexually transmitted and causes pubic itching with visible nits.
  • Louse saliva contains anticoagulants that provoke hypersensitivity and pruritus.

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically included in the Circle of Hebra, the classic distribution pattern seen in scabies?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Circle of Hebra outlines the common anatomical sites affected in classical scabies, typically involving warm, thin - skinned, flexural regions. It includes the interdigital web spaces, flexor wrists, anterior axillary folds, periumbilical area, genitalia, and buttocks.

The scalp is spared in immunocompetent adults, and its involvement is generally seen in infants, young children, or immunocompromised individuals - hence, it is not part of the typical Circle of Hebra.

Explanation of other options:

Interdigital web spaces (Option A): Classic site of mite burrows, definitely included.

Periumbilical region (Option B): Frequently affected part of the circle.

Genitalia (Option D): Commonly involved in both classical and nodular scabies.

Key Takeaways:

  • The scalp is not included in Hebra's circle in classical scabies.
  • Circle of Hebra focuses on flexural and warm areas.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a recognised clinical type of scabies?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bullous scabies is not a formally recognised clinical variant of scabies. While blistering (bullae) may rarely occur, especially in elderly or immunocompromised individuals, it is more accurate to refer to these cases as vesiculobullous scabies, which has some clinical overlap with bullous pemphigoid.

The recognised types of scabies include:

  1. Classical scabies - typical burrows and nocturnal itching
  2. Nodular scabies - persistent pruritic nodules, often in covered areas
  3. Crusted scabies (Norwegian) - hyperkeratotic variant seen in immunocompromised
  4. Infantile scabies - involves scalp, face, palms, and soles
  5. Vesiculobullous scabies - blistering form in infants and elderly
  6. Scalp scabies - limited to the scalp, especially in infants
  7. Animal (zoonotic) scabies - self-limiting and lacks burrows in human skin

Explanation of other options:

Nodular scabies (Option A): A recognised variant with itchy nodules, often on genitalia or axillae, due to hypersensitivity.

Crusted scabies (Option B): Also known as Norwegian scabies, it involves a heavy mite burden and thick crusts in immunosuppressed patients.

Vesiculobullous scabies (Option D): A recognised variant mainly in infants and elderly, may mimic bullous pemphigoid.

Key Takeaways:

  • Bullous scabies is not a formal diagnostic category.
  • Crusted and nodular forms are clinically and epidemiologically significant.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with persistent itchy nodules on the scrotum and genital shaft, as shown in the image below. He was treated for classical scabies 4 weeks ago and reports that the itch has decreased, but these firm, reddish-brown nodules have remained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • The image shows discrete, reddish-brown nodules over the genital area, consistent with nodular scabies - a hypersensitivity reaction to retained mite antigens in the skin.
  • It commonly appears in covered areas like the scrotum, axillae, and groin. Nodules may persist even after successful treatment of classical scabies.
  • This form is highly pruritic, especially at night, and may require topical steroids or calcineurin inhibitors in addition to anti-scabetic therapy.

Explanation of other options:

Lichen planus (Option B): Can appear as violaceous papules but typically on wrists, legs, oral mucosa-not limited to genitals, with a history of scabies.

Fixed drug eruption (Option C): Presents as sharply demarcated erythematous plaques, usually not nodular or pruritic.

Condyloma acuminata (Option D): Wart-like lesions caused by HPV, usually not itchy or related to scabies.

Key Takeaways:

  • Nodular scabies presents as persistent nodules after scabies treatment.
  • Common in axillae, genitalia, and groin due to hypersensitivity.
